awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Elucidating genomic, transcriptomic, and phenotypic consequences of genetic rescue in wild populations
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. This project leverages genetic information to improve the conservation of endangered species. A common strategy to support endangered species is moving individuals from large populations to small, inbred populations, known as “human-assisted migration”. This exchange reduces inbreeding, and often improves the health of recipient populations. However, the exact causes of improvement are poorly understood. Mitchell’s Satyr Butterfly (MSB) is a critically endangered butterfly, and one of many species for which human-assisted migration is being considered. Mitchell’s Satyr once had a large range in the US, but is now restricted to a few small populations Michigan and larger, but disconnected populations in Mississippi. This project will identify the underlying genetic processes that improve offspring health in recipient populations (Michigan) to inform decisions about the choice of populations for assisted-migration. This novel approach will be broadly applicable to conserving other endangered species with disconnected populations that might otherwise face extinction. The fellow will also lead a two-day workshop for undergraduates to increase involvement and inclusion of groups historically underrepresented in field biology. The workshop includes finding and applying to research opportunities, hands-on training in field techniques, and professional network building to increase the students’ confidence in pursuing research.

Research in model systems suggests that inbred individuals are more sensitive to stress, and that genes with reduced genetic variation due to inbreeding are more likely to be expressed mal-adaptively in stressful environments, leading to decreased fitness.  This project investigates the mechanism and extent by which assisted migration (gene flow) mitigates this inbreeding-stress relationship in wild populations by (1) Quantifying genomic variation and inbreeding across the range of MSB through whole-genome sequencing of all extant populations; (2) Assessing critical-thermal maxima in Michigan, Mississippi, and outcrossed individuals, thus linking heat-tolerance phenotype to genomic variation (1), and transcriptional response; and (3) Quantifying gene expression during heat stress in Michigan, Mississippi and outcrossed individuals to identify the genes and molecular pathways most impacted by the inbreeding-stress relationship, and those potentially rescued by outcrossing. The fellow will receive training in whole-genome bioinformatics, receive mentorship in manuscript preparation, and will build collaborative relationships with conservation managers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Mitchell’s Satyr Butterfly (MSB) is critically endangered butterfly with a disjunct range: living in Michigan, Mississippi, and Alabama with an additional subspecies, St. Francis Satyr, in North Carolina. Mitchell’s Satyr faces extinction as small, fragmented northern populations struggle to adapt to increased climate variability and other threats. The introduction of butterflies from larger, healthier southern populations to northern populations, known as “human-assisted migration” is under consideration by various management stakeholders. Assisted migration often improves the health of small populations, but the underlying causes of this effect are poorly understood. This project collected genomic, physiological, and breeding data to inform human-assisted migration, and better understand the species traits likely to lead to successful assisted migration efforts. 

The first step in this process was generating a “reference genome,” the first complete genetic sequence of MSB with identified gene locations. The reference genome allows us to identify regions in the genome that differ between populations, and to identify the genes involved in important functions, such as heat tolerance.  This resource will be publicly available and useable for future research on butterfly evolution and conservation. Following the creation of the reference genome, I sequenced individuals from Michigan, Mississippi, Alabama MSB, as well as St. Francis Satyr. Preliminary analyses suggest that Michigan populations are distinct, and that Mississippi and Alabama populations are more similar to St. Francis Satyr than Michigan MSB. These data also show that northern populations are genetically less diverse than southern populations, likely a consequence of smaller population sizes.

Physiological experiments on southern and northern populations determined that Michigan MSB were more heat tolerant than southern butterflies. This unexpected finding may be due to differences in microhabitat, as southern butterflies are found in more shaded locations than northern butterflies. Michigan butterflies were also more cold tolerant, although both populations can survive temperatures well below freezing. Winter microhabitats may buffer northern butterflies from extreme cold, leading to smaller than expected differences in cold tolerance between north and south.  Lastly, crossbreeding experiments demonstrated that northern and southern butterflies can recognize each other, mate, and successfully lay eggs. While the mating periods in the north and south are separated by six weeks in the wild, we were able to induce butterflies to emerge at the same time using incubation chambers. This indicated that emergence time is flexible potentially allowing butterflies to adjust to changes in seasonality in the future. These crossbred eggs are developing, and the offspring will be assessed for heat and cold tolerance to determine the effect of crossbreeding (i.e. – assisted migration) on thermal limits and fitness. 

Together, these results indicate that despite genetic and physiological differences, these populations are still capable of interbreeding. Following tests of crossbred offspring, we will assess the possible effects of assisted migration on the thermal tolerance and fitness. Tissue samples already taken from both Michigan, Mississippi, Alabama, and eventually, tissues from crossbred offspring will allow us to determine the genes involved in both heat and cold tolerance, linking genetic differences with potentially adaptive traits under warming summers and bouts of extreme cold. Already, these results are informing the management of Mitchell’s Satyr in Michigan, where the priority is to reconnect the small, fragmented populations that remain. This one of the first genomically informed interventions for an endangered insect, thus creating a road map for recovery plans for the many endangered species facing similar challenges.

                 Finally, as part of the fellowship period, I co-created and co-led a week-long workshop to train undergraduates from historically underrepresented groups to conduct field research. This workshop was free to students, and included modules on aquatic and terrestrial insect surveys, avian care, soil sampling, long-term population monitoring, applying to paid research opportunities, and fieldwork equity and safety. The workshop also connected students to professors, graduate students, postdoctoral researchers, and research staff, broadening their academic and professional networks. Thus far, we have taught the course twice to a total of 20 students, and several students have already successfully applied to field-oriented jobs.
